Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Understanding the H3 'apache httpclient overlay'
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=SAititQnHbSUgjG6YsR8Cd3Ok2h_mgoZr1U6TyASr6dy
X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

You should see our slightly altered versions of the Apache classes in 
the source tree. The important things functionally are that (1) you're 
using the right base version of the Apache library (which the Maven 
declarations should handle); (2) the alternate classes in our source 
tree are *earlier in your effective classpath* than the originals.

The changes we made are all marked with comments like "IA CHANGE" or 
"HERITRIX CHANGE". After a quick glance through them to refresh my 
memory, I see they concern:

� injecting our socket-stream 'recording' wrappers, to get a verbatim 
copy of the protocol traffic for later processing/writing
� better support for giant Cookie maps (as necessary in large crawls), 
by allowing replacement of the implementing map class, and a more 
efficient relevant-key-range lookup
� being more tolerant of some URI characters tolerated by browsers but 
previously rejected by the spec-centric Apache code
� noting rather than throwing-as-failure some header anomalies that 
(again) are tolerated by browsers but previously rejected by the 
spec-centric Apache header-parsing code
� replacing some bottleneck synchronized maps with less-bottlenecked 
concurrency-friendly versions

Lots of things would break without these changes, so I think you'd 
notice right away if running a crawl with the wrong (original) classes 
first in your classpath.

- Gordon

On 2/1/13 4:04 AM, jacksonandrew384 wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I'm trying to work through and understand the H3 codebase, but I'm having problems with the Apache Commons HttpClient Overlay. I understand the concept - it's a patched version of the original - but I can't find the modifications or any description of the actual issues that are being resolved.
>
> If I just compile H3 against the vanilla Apache library, will H3 fail? What will go wrong? Does anyone know anything about what this overlay does?
>
> Thanks,
> Andy Jackson
